title: Evolution in a big city - Jason Munshi-South

multiple-choice.question: What is the main subject of the speaker's research?

options.label: A
options.text: The impact of climate change on urban ecosystems

options.label: B
options.text: The evolutionary changes in native wildlife in New York City

options.label: C
options.text: The effects of urbanization on human health

options.label: D
options.text: The conservation of endangered species in urban areas

options.label: D
options.text: All three species mentioned in the talk

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between city and country mice?
What is the purpose of the Manhattan plot in the speaker's research?

options.label: B
options.text: To study the effects of urbanization on mouse behavior

options.label: C
options.text: To analyze the genetic changes in mouse populations over time

title: The power of simple words - Terin Izil

multiple-choice.question: What is the main point of the speaker's argument about using ten-dollar words in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: That using complex vocabulary is essential for good writing.

options.label: B
options.text: That using simple language is always more effective than using complex language.

options.label: C
options.text: That the goal of writing should be to showcase one's vocabulary.

options.label: D
options.text: That the speaker is advocating for writing at a fourth-grade reading level.

multiple-choice.question: What example does the speaker use to illustrate the importance of concise language?

options.label: A
options.text: The example of Patrick Henry's speech.

options.label: B
options.text: The example of Aerosmith's song title.

options.label: C
options.text: The example of Dorothy's phrase from "The Wizard of Oz".

options.label: D
options.text: The example of a Scrabble board.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice for writers in today's world of distractions?

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on using complex vocabulary.

options.label: B
options.text: To focus on brevity and clarity in their writing.

options.label: C
options.text: To write at a fourth-grade reading level.

options.label: D
options.text: To use the same 50 words to fill their pages.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's argument about the effectiveness of using ten-dollar words?

options.label: A
options.text: That they are always understood by the audience.

options.label: B
options.text: That they are always more engaging than simple language.

options.label: C
options.text: That they are rendered worthless if they are not understood.

options.label: D
options.text: That they are essential for good writing.

options.label: A

options.text: It is a suggestion for a game that writers can play to improve their vocabulary.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a metaphor for the importance of brevity in writing.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: That writers should always write at a fourth-grade reading level.

options.label: B
options.text: That writers should focus on using complex vocabulary.

options.label: C
options.text: That writers should know their audience in order to effectively communicate with them.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: That it is more effective than using complex vocabulary.

options.label: D
options.text: That it is only necessary for short writing assignments.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a suggestion for a song title that uses simple language.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: That it is essential for good writing.

options.text: That it is more effective than brevity.

options.label: B
options.text: A partnership between two different species

title: How many universes are there? - Chris Anderson

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of stars in the Milky Way galaxy?
What is the estimated number of galaxies detectable by our telescopes?
According to string theory, how many universes could be part of the multiverse?
What is the estimated number of pocket universes, according to some physicists?
According to quantum theory, how many parallel universes are being spawned every moment?
What is the number of dimensions in the multiverse, according to string theory?
What is the estimated number of atoms in the observable universe?

What is the estimated number of universes, if every atom in the observable universe had its own universe and all of the atoms in all of those universes each had their own universe, and you repeated that for two more cycles?
According to some physicists, what is the number of universes, if you only consider the observable universe?
What is the estimated number of universes, if you consider the space-time continuum to be infinite?

title: How simple ideas lead to scientific discoveries - Adam Savage

multiple-choice.question: Who won the Nobel Prize in Physics for his Feynman diagrams?

What was the result of multiplying the distance between Swenet and Alexandria by 50?
